page.title: 9.4.0: Lesson Overview
page.contents:
In this lesson, you will learn to complete the square to solve non-monic quadratic equations, in which the squared term has a coefficient other than 1.

When you finish this lesson, you will be able to:

  • Complete the square for quadratic expressions of the form \(ax^2+bx+c\) when \(a\) is not 1 and explain the process.
  • Solve quadratic equations in which the squared term coefficient is not 1 by completing the square.

Here are the activities that will help you reach those goals:

  • 9.4.1: Perfect Squares with Coefficients Other than 1
  • 9.4.2: Rewrite Squared Expressions
    • 9.4.2: Self Check
    • 9.3.4: Additional Resources
  • 9.4.3: Standard Form and Squared Factors
    • 9.4.3: Self Check
    • 9.4.3: Additional Resources
  • 9.4.4: Three Different Methods for Solving an Equation
  • 9.4.5: Perfect Square and Squared Factors

After that, you'll practice and review.

  • 9.4.6: Practice
  • 9.4.7: Lesson Summary

page.title: 9.4.1: Perfect Squares with Coefficients Other than 1
page.contents:
Warm Up Activity

Elena says, "\((x+3)^2\) can be expanded into \(x^2+6x+9\). Likewise, \((2x+3)^2\) can be expanded into \(4x^2+6x+9\)."

Find an error in Elena's statement and correct the error. Show your reasoning.

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\((2x+3)^2\) is not equivalent to \(4x^2+6x+9\).

Applying the distributive property to \((2x+3)(2x+3)\) gives \(4x^2+6x+6x+9\), which is \(4x^2+12x+9\).

page.title: 9.4.2: Rewrite Squared Expressions
page.contents:
Activity

  1. Write each expression in standard form:
  1. \((4x+1)^2\)

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\(16x^2+8x+1\)


  1. \((5x−2)^2\)

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\(25x^2−20x+4\)


  1. \((\frac{1}{2}x+7)^2\)

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\(\frac{1}{4}x^2+7x+49\)


  1. \((3x+n)^2\)

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\(9x^2+2(3)(n)x+n^2\) or \(9x^2+6nx+n^2\)


  1. \((kx+m)^2\)

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\(k^2x^2+2kmx+m^2\)


  1. Decide if each expression is a perfect square. If so, write an equivalent expression of the form \((kx+m)^2\). If not, suggest one change to turn it into a perfect square.
  1. \(4x^2+12x+9\)

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

Yes, a perfect square. \((2x+3)^2\)


  1. \(4x^2+8x+25\)

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

No, not a perfect square. Suggested changes include:

  • Changing the coefficient of the linear term to 20 gives \(4x^2+20x+25\), which is equivalent to \((2x+5)^2\).
  • Changing the coefficient of the linear term to -20 gives \(4x^2−20x+25\), which is equivalent to \((2x−5)^2\).
  • Changing the constant term to 4 gives \(4x^2+8x+4\), which is equivalent to \((2x+2)^2\).

Video: Rewrite Squared Expressions

Watch the following video to learn more about rewriting squared expressions.

page.title: 9.4.2: Self Check
page.contents: Find the equivalent factored expression for \(4x^2+12x+9\).

answer.response: Incorrect. Let's try again a different way: While 4 is the greatest common factor (GCF) of the first two terms, it is not a factor of 9. The answer is \((2x+3)^2\).
Incorrect. Let's try again a different way: This is equivalent to \(4x^2-12x+9\). The answer is \((2x+3)^2\).
That's correct! Check yourself: When multiplied using distribution, \((2x + 3)(2x + 3)\) equals the given expression.
Incorrect. Let's try again a different way: This is equivalent to \(4x^2-9\). The answer is \((2x+3)^2\).

page.title: 9.4.2: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Factoring Perfect Square Trinomials

To factor perfect square trinomials, follow the formulas:

\(a^2+2ab+b^2=(a+b)^2\)

\(a^2-2ab+b^2=(a-b)^2\)

Let's look at an example of how to factor perfect square trinomials.

Example

Factor \(9x^2+12x+4\).

Step 1
Does the trinomial fit the perfect square trinomial pattern, \(a^2+2ab+b\)?

  • Is the first term a perfect square? Write it as a square, \(a^2\).
    Is \(9x^2a\) perfect square?
    Yes — write it as \((3x)^2\).
    \(\begin{array}{l}9x^2\;+\;12x\;+\;4 \\ (3x)^2\;\end{array}\)
  • Is the last term a perfect square? Write it as a square, \(b^2\).
    Is 4 a perfect square?
    Yes — write it as \((2)^2\).
    \(\begin{array}{l}9x^2\;+\;12x\;+\;4 \\ (3x)^2\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;(2)^2\end{array}\)
  • Check the middle term. Is it \(2ab\)?
    Is \(12x\) twice the product of \(3x\) and 2?
    Does it match?
    Yes, so we have a perfect trinomial.

\(\begin{array}{c}9x^2\;\;\;\;\;\;+\;\;\;\;\;\;12x\;\;\;\;\;\;+\;\;\;\;\;\;4\; \\ (3x)^2\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;(2)^2 \\ (3x)^2\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;(2)^2 \\ {\style{color:green}\searrow}\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;{\style{color:green}\swarrow} \\ 2(3x)(2) \\ 12x\;\end{array}\)

Step 2
Write the square of the binomial.
\(9x^2+12x+4\)
\(\begin{array}{l}a^2\;\;\;\;\;\;+2\cdot a\cdot b+b^2 \\ \;({\style{color:red}3}{\style{color:red}x})^2\;+2 \cdot {\style{color:red}3}{\style{color:red}x} \cdot {\style{color:purple}2}+{\style{color:purple}2}^2\; \\ \;\;\;\;\;\;\;(a+b)^2\; \\ \;\;\;\;\;({\style{color:red}3}{\style{color:red}x}+{\style{color:green}2})^{\style{color:green}2}\end{array}\)

Step 3
Check.
\((3x+2)^2\)
\((3x)^2+2 \cdot 3x \cdot 2+2^2\)
\(9x^2+12x+4 ✔\)

Try It: Factoring Perfect Square Trinomials

Factor \(9x^2-30x+25\).

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Here is how to factor a perfect square trinomial:

Step 1
Write the first term as \(a^2\) and the last constant as \(b^2=25\).
\(a^2=(3x)^2\), \(b^2=5^2\)

Make sure the middle term is \(2ab\).
\(2ab=2(3x)(5)=30x\)

Step 2
Factor the binomial into: \(a^2-2ab+b^2=(a-b)^2\).
\((3x-5)^2\)

Step 3
Check.

\((3x-5)(3x-5)\)
\(=9x^2-15x-15x+25\)
\(=9x^2-30x+25\)

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 9.4.3: Standard Form and Squared Factors
page.contents:
Activity

  1. For each expression, find the value of \(c\) to make a perfect square in standard form \((ax^2+bx+c)\).
  1. \(100x^2+80x+c\)

Enter the value of \(c\).

Correct! 16. Standard form: \(100x^2+80x+16\).

The correct answer is 16. Standard form: \(100x^2+80x+16\).

  1. \(36x^2−60x+c\)

Enter the value of \(c\).

Correct! 25. Standard form: \(36x^2−60x+25\).

The correct answer is 25. Standard form: \(36x^2−60x+25\).

  1. \(25x^2+40x+c\)

Enter the value of \(c\).

Correct! 16. Standard form: \(25x^2+40x+16\).

The correct answer is 16. Standard form: \(25x^2+40x+16\).

  1. \(0.25x^2−14x+c\)

Enter the value of \(c\).

Correct! 196. Standard form: \(0.25x^2−14x+196\).

The correct answer is 196. Standard form: \(0.25x^2−14x+196\).

  1. For each expression, refer to your responses in question 1 to help write an equivalent expression in the form of squared factors \((kx+m)^2\).
  1. \(100x^2+80x+c\)

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\((10x+4)^2\)


  1. \(36x^2−60x+c\)

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\((6x-5)^2\)


  1. \(25x^2+40x+c\)

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\((5x+4)^2\)


  1. \(0.25x^2−14x+c\)

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\((0.5x-14)^2\)


  1. Write your own pair of equivalent expressions.
  1. Create an expression in standard form \((ax^2+bx+c)\).

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

Answers will vary. One expression in standard form is: \(49x^2+14x+1\).


  1. Now write the same equivalent expression in the form of squared factors \((kx+m)^2\).

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

Answers will vary. Using the expression above, for example, the squared factor of \(49x^2+14x+1\) would be \((7x+1)^2\).


  1. Solve each equation by completing the square.
  1. \(25x^2+40x=-12\)

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\(\begin{aligned} 25 x^{2}+40 x &=-12 \\ 25 x^{2}+40 x+12 &=0 \\ 25 x^{2}+40 x+12+4 &=4 \\ 25 x^{2}+40 x+16 &=4 \\ (5 x+4)^{2} &=4 \\ \sqrt{(5 x+4)^{2}} &=\sqrt{4} \\ 5 x+4 &=2 \\ 5 x+4 &=-2 \\ 5 x &=-2 \\ 5 x &=-6 \\ \\ x=-\frac{2}{5} & \text { and } x=-\frac{6}{5} \end{aligned} \)


  1. \(36x^2−60x+10=-6\)

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\(\begin{aligned} 36 x^{2}-60 x+10 &=-6 \\ 36 x^{2}-60 x+10+15 &=-6+15 \\ 36 x^{2}-60 x+25 &=9 \\ (6 x-5)^{2} &=9 \\ \sqrt{(6 x-5)^{2}} &=\sqrt{9} \\ 6 x-5 &=3 \\ 6 x-5 &=-3 \\ 6 x &=8 \\ 6 x &=2 \\ \\ x=\frac{8}{6}=\frac{4}{3} & \text { and } x=\frac{2}{6}=\frac{1}{3} \end{aligned}\)

answer.response: Incorrect. Let's try again a different way: This is the number that is added to each side, but not the solution. The correct answer is \(x=\frac{1}{5}\), \(x= -\frac{7}{5}\).
That's correct! Check yourself: 9 should be added to each side, then the new equation becomes \((5x+3)^2=16\). When solved, these are the two solutions.
Incorrect. Let's try again a different way: Make sure to take the square root of both sides of the equation. The correct answer is \(x=\frac15\), \(x= -\frac75\).
Incorrect. Let's try again a different way: The solution is not where the factor equals 0. The correct answer is \(x=\frac15\), \(x= -\frac75\).

page.title: 9.4.3: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Find the Value to Make a Perfect Square and Solve

In earlier lessons, we worked with perfect squares such as \((x+1)^2\) and \((x-5)(x-5)\). We learned that their equivalent expressions in standard form follow a predictable pattern:

  • In general, \((x+m)^2\) can be written as \(x^2+2mx +m^2\).
  • If a quadratic expression of the form \(ax^2+bx +c\) is a perfect square, and the value of \(a\) is 1, then the value of \(b\) is \(2m\), and the value of \(c\) is \(m^2\) for some value of \(m\).

In this lesson, the variable in the factors being squared had a coefficient other than 1, for example \((3x+1)^2\) and \((2x-5)(2x-5)\). Their equivalent expression in standard form also followed the same pattern we saw earlier.

Squared factors

Standard form

\((3x+1)^2\)

\((3x)^2+2(3x)(1)+1^2\) or \(9x^2+6x +1\)

\((2x-5)^2\)

\((2x)^2+2(2x)(-5) +(-5)^2\)  or \(4x^2-20x +25\)

In general, \((kx+m)^2\) can be written as:

\((kx)^2+2 (kx)(m) +m^2\) or \(k^2x^2+2kmx +m^2\)

If a quadratic expression is of the form \(ax^2+bx+c\), then:

  • the value of \(a\) is \(k^2\)
  • the value of \(b\) is \(2km\)
  • the value of \(c\) is \(m^2\)

We can use this pattern to help us complete the square and solve equations when the squared term \(x^2\) has a coefficient other than 1—for example: \(16x^2+40x =11\).

What constant term \(c\) can we add to make the expression on the left of the equal sign a perfect square? And how do we write this expression as squared factors?

  • 16 is \(4^2\), so the squared factors could be \((4x + m)^2\).
  • 40 is equal to \(2(4m)\), so \(2(4m) = 40\) or \(8m=40\). This means that \(m = 5\).
  • If \(c\) is \(m^2\), then \(c =52\) or \(c=25\).
  • So the expression \(16x^2+40x +25\) is a perfect square and is equivalent to \((4x+5)^2\).

Let's solve the equation \(16x^2+40x =11\) by completing the square!

\(\begin{array}{rcl}\;16^2+40x\;&=&\;11 \\ 16^2+40x+25\;&=&\;11+25 \\ (4x+5)^2&=&36\;\end{array}\)

\(4x+5=6\;\;\;\;\mathrm{or}\;\;\;\;4x+5=-6\\\;\;\;\;\;\;\;4x=1\;\;\;\mathrm{or}\;\;\;\;4x=-11\\\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;x=\frac14\;\;\mathrm{or}\;\;\;\;x=\frac{-11}4\)

Try It: Find the Value to Make a Perfect Square and Solve

Solve \(4x^2+28x=-13\).

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Here is how to solve this equation by completing the square:

Step 1
To be a perfect square, \((2x+m)^2\) is needed.
\(4x^2+28x=-13\)

Step 2
Find the value of \(m\) to make a perfect square.
\(2(2m) = 28\), so \(m = 7\).

Step 3
Find \(c= m^2\).
\(c=m^2=7^2=49\)

Step 4
Add \(c\) to both sides.
\(4x^2+28x+49=-13+49\)

Step 5
Factor and simplify.
\((2x+7)^2=36\)

Step 6
Take the square root of both sides. Remember the plus or minus.
\(\sqrt{(2x+7)^2}=\sqrt{36}\)
\( 2x+7= \pm 6\)

Step 7
Write two equations and solve.
\(2x+7=6\)            \(2x+7=-6\)
\(x= -\frac12\)            \(x=-\frac{13}{2}\)

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 9.4.4: Three Different Methods for Solving an Equation
page.contents:
Optional Activity

Here are three methods for solving \(3x^2+8x+5=0\).

Carefully examine each method.

Method 1:

\(\begin{array}{rcl} 3 x^{2}+8 x+5 &=&0 \\ (3 x+5)(x+1) &=&0 \\ x+1 &=&0 \\ 3 x+5 &=&0 \\ x &=&-1 \\ 3 x &=&-5 \\ x &=&-\frac{5}{3} \end{array}\)

\(x=-\frac{5}{3} \text { and } x=-1\)

Method 2:

\(\begin{aligned} 3 x^{2}+8 x+5 &=0 \\ 9 x^{2}+24 x+15 &=0 \\ (3 x)^{2}+8(3 x)+15 &=0 \\ U^{2}+8 U+15 &=0 \\ (U+5)(U+3) &=0 \\ U+5 &=0 \\ U+3 &=0 \\ U &=-5 \\ U &=-3 \\ 3 x &=-5 \\ 3 x &=-3 \end{aligned} \)

\(x=-\frac{5}{3} \text { and } x=-1\)

Method 3:

\(\begin{aligned} 3 x^{2}+8 x+5 &=0 \\ 9 x^{2}+24 x+15 &=0 \\ 9 x^{2}+24 x+16 &=1 \\ (3 x+4)^{2} &=1 \\ 3 x+4 &=1 \\ 3 x+4 &=-1\end{aligned}\)

\(x=-\frac{5}{3} \text { and } x=-1\)

Once you understand the methods, use each method at least one time to solve these equations.

  1. \(5x^2+17x+6=0\)

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

Method 1 is used here, but any of the three methods would work.

\(\begin{array}{rcl} 5 x^2+17 x+6 &=& 0 \\ (5x+2)(x+3) &=& 0 \\ 5x+2 &=& 0 \\ 5x &=& -2 \\ x&=& - \frac{2}{5} \\ x+3 &=& 0 \\ x &=& -3 \end{array} \)

\(x=-\frac{2}{5} \text { and } x =-3\)


  1. \(6x^2+19x=-10\)

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

Method 2 is used here, but any of the three methods would work.

\(\begin{array}{rcl}6x^2+19x&=&-10\\6x^2+19x+10&=&0 \\ 36x^2+114x+60&=&0 \\ (6x)^2+19(6x)+60&=&0 \\ U^2+19U+60&=&0 \\ (U+15)(U+4)&=&0 \\ U+15&=&0 \\ U&=&-15\\6x&=&-15 \\ x&=&-\frac{15}6=-\frac52 \\ (U+4)&=&0 \\ U&=&-4 \\ 6x&=&-4 \\ x&=&-\frac46=-\frac23\end{array}\)

\(x=-\frac{5}{2} \text { and } x=-\frac{2}{3}\)


  1. \(8x^2−33x+4=0\)

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

Method 1 is used here, but any of the three methods would work.

\(\begin{array}{rcl} 8 x^{2}-33 x+4 &=&0 \\ (8 x-1)(x-4) &=&0 \\ 8 x-1 &=&0 \\ 8 x &=&1 \\ x &=&\frac{1}{8} \\ x-4 &=0 \\ x &=&4 \end{array} \)

\(x=\frac{1}{8} \text { and } x=4\)


  1. \(8x^2−26x=-21\)

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

Method 1 is used here, but any of the three methods would work.

\(\begin{array}{rcl} 8 x^{2}-26 x &=&-21 \\ 8 x^{2}-26 x+21 &=&0 \\ (4 x-7)(2 x-3) &=&0 \\ 4 x-7 &=&0 \\ 4 x &=&7 \\ x &=&\frac{7}{4} \\ 2 x-3 &=&0 \\ 2 x &=&3 \\ x &=&\frac{3}{2} \\ x=\frac{7}{4} \text { and } x=\frac{3}{2} \end{array} \)

  1. \(10x^2+37x=36\)

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

Method 3 is used here, but any of the three methods would work.

\(\begin{array}{rcl} 10x^{2}+37x &=&36 \\ \frac{(10x^{2}+37x)}{10} &=&\frac{36}{10} \\ x^{2}+\frac{37}{10}x &=&\frac{36}{10} \\ x^2+\frac{37}{10}x+((\frac{1}{2})(\frac{37}{10}))^{2} &=&\frac{36}{10}+((\frac{1}{2})(\frac{37}{10}))^{2} \\ x^2+\frac{37}{10}x+\frac{1369}{400} &=&\frac{36}{10}+\frac{1369}{400} \\ x^2+\frac{37}{10}x+\frac{1369}{400} &=&\frac{2809}{400} \\ (x+\frac{37}{20})^{2} &=&\frac{2809}{400} \\ \sqrt{(x+\frac{37}{20})^{2}} &=&\sqrt{\frac{2809}{400}}\\ x+\frac{37}{20} &=&\frac{53}{20} \\ x &=&\frac{16}{20} \\ x &=&\frac{4}{5} \\ x+\frac{37}{20} &=&-\frac{53}{20} \\ x &=&-\frac{90}{20} \\ x &=&-\frac{9}{2} \end{array} \)

\(x=\frac{4}{5} \text { and } x=-\frac{9}{2}\)

  1. \(12x^2+20x−77=0\)

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

Method 3 is used here, but any of the three methods would work.

\(\begin{array}{rcl}12x^2+20x-77&=&0\\12x^2+20x&=&77\\\frac{\left(12x^2+20x\right)}{12}&=&\frac{77}{12}\\x^2+\frac{20}{12}x&=&\frac{77}{12}\\x^2+\frac{20}{12}x+\left(\left(\frac12\right)\left(\frac{20}{12}\right)\right)^2&=&\frac{77}{12}+\left(\left(\frac12\right)\left(\frac{20}{12}\right)\right)^2\\x^2+\frac{20}{12}x+\frac{100}{144}&=&\frac{77}{12}+\frac{100}{144}=\frac{924}{144}+\frac{100}{144}\\x^2+\frac{20}{12}x+\frac{100}{144}&=&\frac{1024}{144}\\\left(x+\frac{10}{12}\right)^2&=&\frac{1024}{144}\\\sqrt{\left(x+\frac{10}{12}\right)^2}&=&\sqrt{\frac{1024}{144}}\\x+\frac{10}{12}&=&\frac{32}{12}\\x+\frac{10}{12}&=&-\frac{32}{12}\\x&=&\frac{22}{12}\\x&=&-\frac{42}{12}\\x&=&\frac{11}6\\x&=&-\frac{21}6=-\frac72\end{array}\)

\(x=\frac{11}6\text{ and }x=-\frac72\)


Extending Your Thinking

  1. Solve the equation \(2x^2-3x+1=0\), then choose the two roots. 
  1. \(x= -\frac32\)
  2. \(x= -\frac52\)
  3. \(x = 1\)
  4. \(x=\frac52\)
  5. \(x=\frac12\)

Enter the two roots.

Compare your answer:

C. \(x = 1\), E. \(x = \frac12\)


  1. Explain your reasoning for your solution.

Enter your reasoning.

Compare your answer:

Using the techniques of this lesson, the first step is to divide both sides of the equation by 2 to obtain \(x^2-\frac{3}{2}x+\frac{1}{2}=0\), and then complete the square.

page.title: 9.4.5: Perfect Square and Squared Factors
page.contents:
Cool Down Activity

  1. Answer the following questions for expression \(4x^2−28x+c\).
  1. Find the value of \(c\) to make the expression a perfect square.

Enter the value of \(c\).

Correct! 49. Standard form: \(4x^2−28x+49\).

The correct answer is 49. Standard form: \(4x^2−28x+49\).

  1. Write an equivalent expression in the form of squared factors.

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

Squared factors: \((2x−7)^2\).

  1. Solve the equation \(4x^2−28x=-33\) by completing the square. Show your reasoning.

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\(\begin{aligned} 4 x^{2}-28 x &=-33 \\ 4 x^{2}-28 x+49 &=-33+49 \\ (2 x-7)^{2} &=16 \\ \sqrt{(2 x-7)^{2}} &=\sqrt{16} \\ 2 x-7 &=4 \\ 2 x-7 &=-4 \\ 2 x &=11 \\ 2 x &=3 \end{aligned}\)

\(x=\frac{11}{2} \text { and } x=\frac{3}{2}\)

page.title: 9.4.6: Practice
page.contents:
Complete the following questions to practice the skills you have learned in this lesson.

  1. Select three expressions that are perfect squares.

Correct! \(9x^2+24x+16\), \((7-3x)^2\), \((1-2x)(-2x+1)\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 9.4.1 and 9.4.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answers are: \(9x^2+24x+16\), \((7-3x)^2\), \((1-2x)(-2x+1)\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Find the missing number that makes the expression a perfect square.
  1. \(49x^2-\_\_\_\_\_\_x+16\)

    Enter the missing number

Correct! \(49x^2−56x+16\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 9.4.1 and 9.4.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 56. \(49x^2−56x+16\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \(36x^2+\_\_\_\_\_\_x+4\)

    Enter the missing number.

Correct! \(36x^2+24x+4\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 9.4.1 and 9.4.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 24. \(36x^2+24x+4\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \(4x^2-\_\_\_\_\_\_x+25\)

    Enter the missing number.

Correct! \(4x^2−20x+25\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 9.4.1 and 9.4.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 20. \(4x^2−20x+25\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \(9x^2+\_\_\_\_\_\_x+9\)

    Enter the missing number.

Correct! \(9x^2+18x+9\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 9.4.1 and 9.4.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 18. \(9x^2+18x+9\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \(121x^2+\_\_\_\_\_\_x+9\)

    Enter the missing number.

Correct! \(121x^2+66x+9\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 9.4.1 and 9.4.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 66. \(121x^2+66x+9\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Choose the factored form of the expression.
  1. \(49x^2-56x+16\)

Correct! \((7x-4)^2\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 9.4.1 and 9.4.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: \((7x-4)^2\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \(36x^2+24x+4\)

Correct! \(4(3x+1)^2\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 9.4.1 and 9.4.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: \(4(3x+1)^2\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \(4x^2-20x+25\)

Correct! \((2x-5)^2\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 9.4.1 and 9.4.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: \((2x-5)^2\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \(121x^2+66x+9\)

Correct! \((11x+3)^2\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 9.4.1 and 9.4.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: \((11x+3)^2\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Find the missing number that makes the expression a perfect square.
  1. \(9x^2+42x+\_\_\_\_\_\)

    Enter the missing number.

Correct! \(9x^2+42x+49\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 9.4.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 49. \(9x^2+42x+49)\. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \(49x^2-28x+\_\_\_\_\_\)

    Enter the missing number.

Correct! \(49x^2-28x+4\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 9.4.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 4. \(49x^2-28x+4\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \(25x^2+110x+\_\_\_\_\_\)

    Enter the missing number.

Correct! \(25x^2+110x+121\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 9.4.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 121. \(25x^2+110x+121\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \(64x^2-144x+\_\_\_\_\_\)

    Enter the missing number.

Correct! \(64x^2-144x+81\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 9.4.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 81. \(64x^2-144x+81\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \(4x^2+24x+\_\_\_\_\_\)

    Enter the missing number.

Correct! \(4x^2+24x+36\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 9.4.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 36. \(4x^2+24x+36\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Based on your responses in question 4 above, choose the factored form of the expression.
  1. \(9x^2+42x+\_\_\_\_\_\)

Correct! \((3x+7)^2\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 9.4.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: \((3x+7)^2\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \(49x^2-28x+\_\_\_\_\_\)

Correct! \((7x-2)^2\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 9.4.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: \((7x-2)^2\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \(25x^2+110x+\_\_\_\_\_\)

Correct! \((5x+11)^2\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 9.4.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: \((5x+11)^2\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \(64x^2-144x+\_\_\_\_\_\)

Correct! \((8x-9)^2\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 9.4.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: \((8x-9)^2\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \(4x^2+24x+\_\_\_\_\_\)

Correct! \((2x+6)^2\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 9.4.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: \((2x+6)^2\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. For each expression, find the value of \(c\) to make a perfect square in standard form \((ax^2+bx+c)\).
  1. \(4x^2+4x+c\)

    Enter the value of \(c\).

Correct! \(4x^2+4x+1\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 9.4.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 1. \(4x^2+4x+1\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \(25x^2-30x+c\)

    Enter the value of \(c\).

Correct! \(25x^2−30x+9\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 9.4.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 9. \(25x^2−30x+9\) . You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. For each equation, solve by completing the square, then choose a solution.
  1. \(4x^2+4x+c\)

Correct! \(-\frac12\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 9.4.3–9.4.5. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: \(-\frac12\)x=-12. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \(25x^2-30x+c\)

Correct! \(x=\frac35\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 9.4.3–9.4.5. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: \(x=\frac35\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

page.title: 9.4.7: Lesson Summary
page.contents:
In this lesson, you learned how to:

  • Complete the square for quadratic expressions of the form \(ax^2+bx+c\) when \(a\) is not 1 and explain the process.
  • Solve quadratic equations in which the squared term coefficient is not 1 by completing the square.

Here are the activities that helped you reach those goals:

  • 9.4.1: Perfect Squares with Coefficients Other than 1
    • In this activity, you found the error when completing the square when the leading coefficient is not 1.
  • 9.4.2: Rewrite Squared Expressions
    • In this activity, you determined if a quadratic expression was a perfect square. If it was not a perfect square, you made a suggestion that could make the expression a perfect square.
    • 9.4.2: Self Check
    • 9.4.2: Additional Resources
  • 9.4.3: Standard Form and Squared Factors
    • In this activity, you found the value of \(c\) to complete the square of the quadratic then wrote the quadratic in factored form.
    • 9.4.3: Self Check
    • 9.4.3: Additional Resources
  • 9.4.4: Three Different Methods for Solving an Equation
    • In this optional activity, you explored three different methods for solving quadratic equations then used each method to solve an equation.
  • 9.4.5: Perfect Square and Squared Factors
    • In this activity, you completed the square then solved the quadratic equation.

After these activities, you completed the following practice:

  • 9.4.6: Practice

Checking In

On a scale of 1 to 5, how confident do you feel about the learning goals of this lesson?

Correct!

If you’ve answered 3 or less, be sure to reach out to your teacher before starting the next lesson.
